chargeHist.descr: Drive or Operate Vehicle w/o Consent

result.execSummary:
The defendant Eric Jamison Brewer was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Drive or Operate Vehicle w/o Consent, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.23(3).
  • Vehicle Operator Flee/Elude Officer, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.04(3).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
If Probation is revoked and sent to jail or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
If revoked and sent to prison, DOC shall withhold 25% of all inmates monies to pay fines/costs with the balance due as a condition of extended supervision/parole.
Expungement under 973.015 upon; Successful completion of probation.

Not to consume alcoholic beverages, illegal drugs or possess drug paraphernalia. 
Not to be on the premises of any tavern or business whose sole purpose is the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
Not possess controlled substances except for those medications specifically prescribed for him/her by a health care professional. 
Not to possess needles/syringes except with a valid prescription.

Counseling/assessments/treatment deemed appropriate by agent. 
AODA assessment.
Provide DNA sample and be responsible for the cost.

Good faith effort to seek/maintain employment. 
Attend school/obtain HSED.

11:46 AM Prosecuting attorney Claudia T. Johnson appeared by phone for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Eric Jamison Brewer appeared by phone.  Attorney Stephanie M. Rock appeared by phone for Eric Jamison Brewer. 
Plea questionnaire efiled. Defendant waives right to in person appearance and agrees to proceed by phone. Advised and waived rights. 
Defendant enters plea of no contest to counts 2 and 3- Court finds Deft. guilty. Remaining counts DRI.
Court received character letters. 
State recommends 120 days imposed and stayed in favor of 3 years probation. 60 days conditional jail time.
950/Marsy's Law complied with. 
Defense requests 2 years probation with expungement.
